user_message:
<misra_rule>
MISRA C 2023 Rule 17.8 is: A function parameter should not be modified.
Note that the object referred to by a pointer parameter may be modified, but the pointer itself shall not be modified.
</misra_rule>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- is_rule_violated: whether the rule is violated or not (true/false),
- scenario: a specific violation scenario.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of OS_MutSemDelete:
```c
int32 OS_MutSemDelete(osal_id_t sem_id)
{
    OS_object_token_t token;
    int32             return_code;

    return_code = OS_ObjectIdGetById(OS_LOCK_MODE_EXCLUSIVE, LOCAL_OBJID_TYPE, sem_id, &token);
    if (return_code == OS_SUCCESS)
    {
        return_code = OS_MutSemDelete_Impl(&token);

        /* Complete the operation via the common routine */
        return_code = OS_ObjectIdFinalizeDelete(return_code, &token);
    }

    return return_code;
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are close to the target function OS_MutSemDelete:
typedef uint32 osal_id_t
...
typedef struct OS_object_token OS_object_token_t
</additional code>
<target_code>
Here is the code fragment that you need to analyze:
```c
int32 OS_MutSemDelete(osal_id_t sem_id)
```
Focus on the above code fragment and judge whether it violates the rule 17.8 or not.
</target_code>
scenario: No violation: the parameter sem_id (type osal_id_t) is passed by value and is not assigned to or modified anywhere in OS_MutSemDelete. The function only passes sem_id to other routines; local variable token is used and passed by address (allowed per the rule).
